results.title: Communication: getting it going
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education and George Cass
results.brief_description: This program shows some of the ways the theme communication can be developed in primary and postprimary English programs. The English framework encourages these ideas as a means of extending and enriching the experiences of all students.

results.title: Communication: getting in touch
results.creator_credit: Bosustow Entertainment, Nick Bosustow and Sam Weiss
results.brief_description: An alien colony settles on earth and language differences present a problem. This film shows in a humorous way how communicating with others involves getting in touch with their ways of exchanging information; and how to overcome the three barriers to communication: linguistic, sociological and personal. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Communication without speech
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Recent advances in technology have enabled the development of a range of sophisticated communication devices which, with the assistance of microprocessors, enables students with severe communication impairment to communicate, using voice and print.

results.title: Communication satellites
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems of World Order”.
Explores the world implications of sophisticated ommunication facilities, particularly with respect to technologically advanced and underdeveloped countries. Focuses on control problems of potential power of the Intersat and the Comsat. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Communication games in a language programme
results.brief_description: Shows a London intensive English language course with tertiary foreign students , based on games involving information gaps or opinion gaps which force students to communicate, seek information, argue and disagree.

results.title: Communication case book
results.brief_description: Four case histories exploring an area of communication. The Case of the tuned-out mind: Communication is a two-way exchange in which the situation alters as each party responds to the other. The Case of the wrong wave-length: The ability to find and use the particular approach that will be most effective with each different individual. The Case of the chain-reaction: How we communicate is as important as what we communicate. The Case of the silent yell: Unspoken communication and its effect on goals and on our relationship with other people.

results.title: Communication by voice and action
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the importance of gestures, expression, posture, voice and body movement in communication. Communication is a two way process between the speaker and the listener, so things must be said and done to clearly indicate the speaker’s thoughts and feelings.

results.title: Communication at work
results.creator_credit: George Pashuk and University of New South Wales. Tertiary Education Research Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Trigger series 7. Managing people”.
Dramatisations of seven brief interactions between staff members. Designed to trigger discussion on communication at work.
